title: Robo 3d R1 X Axis Stepper Motor Mount For Cable Chain System

description.text: A simple clip round mount to attach the cable chain directly onto the extruder stepper motor without the need to make a new X carriage. I loved the cable chain idea but didn't like the idea of having to throw away the original X axis carriage to make it fit the printer, I came up with this which simply clips around the motor and if preferred can be held in place with 1 screw in the corner of the motor. The screw is not needed as it fit very well round the motor body.

author: Chromosomebody

title: Hex-a-pod I made for a Boy Scout High Adventure, 18 boys and 5 adults each built one of these arduino based hexapods.

description.text:
This is a remake of Barry Scott's Hexapod Ant, many thanks to him! I spent about 500 hours converting his design into this, I was learning Blender as I went ;-P

Also a thanks and credit goes out to danf at:
http://astromech.net/forums/forum.php
for helping me get Bill Porter's ( http://www.billporter.info/2010/06/05/playstation-2-controller-arduino-library-v1-0/ ) PS2 Wireless Controller arduino library working.

I recommend printing most of the parts at 35% to keep weight down, except the upper leg and mid leg pieces, I print them at 65% due to them needing to be strong, the 4 main body parts at 20% to conserve weight . Also the Jaws I print at 100% and am thinking of upgrading them to accept a metal servo horn, the servo connection is certainly a weak spot. Our arduino code is available and open, feel free to use it and if you improve it please upload your code for all to share: https://github.com/ari86m/Kinne-Hexapod-Software
RGB LED's in his nostrils and ultra-sonics in his eyes , still need code to operate at this time.
You will need to print:
1 head
1 tail
1 body spacer
both tops and both bottoms and then we fused them together using acetone since we build our hexapods from ABS.
6 upper legs
6 mid legs
6 leg spacers
6 feet
6 servoless legs
12 lower legs
1 eyes
1 Arduino mount
1 left pincher
1 right pincher

53 parts in total, about 120 hours of printing, depending on your printers speed.

BOM:

1 arduino mega
1 5300 mAh battery or close
1 9volt battery
13 MG996 servo's
1 PS2 wireless controller
1 ultra-sonic sensor

We made our own arduino shield to plug the servos into. We run the arduino off the 9volt battery and the servos off the 7.3 or 7.4 volt 5300 mAh battery to avoid problems with noise electrically. The Body Tops can use either the plastic servo horns or a metal ones, I recommend metal servo horns because I have stripped some plastic ones causing a broken leg ;-P

Since this was a Scouting project, we had a budget. We spent about $175USD for everything except the plastic for the 3D printers. $5 servo's, $20 battery, $14 Arduino Mega, $13 PS2 Wireless Controller, the cheapest eBay has to offer. A better battery would be smart, but the rest works just fine.

If you wish to add a third degree of movement to the legs you just replae the "servoless leg" with a "midleg" servo holder, they are the same. We used 2 degrees of motion to keep the osts and weight down. We had a Scout budget and when I did add the third servo to each leg the hexapod had a hard time with the weight. It may have been the fault of the cheap batteries we used, I am not sure.

I will add wiring diagrams and advice soon.

Some videos:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=RH3sS--7Cvs

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=kSAhqxDhP_E

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=SAkhP33Q4Kg

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=KN3hOfVMdiU

title: Tinkerplay Dragonfly Pixie character for dual material printing

description.text:
This figure is based on parts from the Pixie character in the Tinkerplay app. Check it out, it's free for iOS, Android and Windows.

The parts are taken mostly from the app, and the Tinkerplay team has made sure that they are easily printable.

All I've done is make some slight modifications to make this particular model possible. If you have a dual extruder printer, go nuts!

The head has been separated for dual color printing, so the hair & eyes are one color, and the face another.

The wings are also separated for dual color printing - print 2x of each of the frame and pattern parts.

The torso now has 4 wing attachments instead of 2, and the pelvis has a place for attaching a tail. Make sure to print the tail support too, otherwise the tail ball won't print.

My son is a voracious crayon user. unfortunately he likes to put the maximum pressure to get the darkest colors and we end up with a lot of broken crayons. I designed this for two reasons, one to support the crayon the way he colors, and two to hold the broken crayons so they are not wasted.

Another benefit would be small hands, as the size is a bit bigger than of a Ticonderoga Tri-write pencil and you can use the smaller less expensive crayons compared to the larger triangular ones.

I have added version 3 of the design. My son asked for a more controlled way to push the crayon fragment out. Using the screw library in MCAD, I added an auger 'thread" to the pusher and subtracted the same from the holder body.

It's best if you have the knurl surface library (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:32122) in your MCAD library folder as this is used to provide some bit at the tip of the holder.

I printed at 0.2mm, 30% fill, and 1.2mm wall thickness and it's very strong.

The pusher it in case the crayon slips in too far, but a pencil will work just as good.

The auger is if you want more control over the amount of "push" you give to the crayon fragment.

Use: Just slide the crayon in and add a small rubber band to hold it tight. (I planned for an o-ring but can find the one I had in mind so I'll check the hardware store next time I'm in there.) You can roll the rubber band down to remove/replace the crayon too.

title: Tinkerplay Mermaid for dual material printing

description.text:
This is the Mermaid character from the Tinkerplay app, modified with a pattern for dual extrusion printing. (Check out the app, it is free and a lot of fun)

The parts were designed by the creative geniuses at Tinkerplay, and highly optimized for 3D printing.

The parts included here have the head separated into the Crest and Head, and then tail has been set up with a pattern of scales. For example, you should print "tail d scales printable" with "tail d scales pattern" etc.

Patterns were generated with Autodesk's Project Shapeshifter, another fun tool for making printable stuff.

title: Mobius Case
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I designed this to slice nicely with cura and a printer with 0.4mm nozzle at 0.2mm layer height. Print without support.
It is confirmed working with the B and C lens, I have not tested the A lens yet. Will fit the ZMR bobbins spacing.

Secured by one 20mm M3 screw (hold the two parts together and tap the thread into the plastic with the screw). Add some foam tape to the inside top and your good to go.

Check the video for more info. Enjoy :)
https://youtu.be/yf7kNTewlxU

An improved version of thing:950808 a puzzle where a dodecahedron is formed from 6 pieces. In this version an asterisk is placed over each sphere. This has several advantages: attempts to make incorrect joins are immediately seen to be wrong; correct placements are immediately confirmed; and the final assembled version shows how correct piece placement works. It is a more symmetric puzzle composed of two copies of three types of pieces. OpenSCAD code is included and contains hints to the solution of the puzzle.

Print 2 copies of each puzzle type to construct a complete puzzle. The pieces are designed to be printed with support and with the spheres and holes on top. On my Replicator I print them with PLA using 0.3 mm layers and 2 shells. The puzzle is more attractive and enjoyable to work on if each type is printed in a different color.

comments.text: Added an openSCAD program, display_ans.scad, that shows the puzzle answers on a terminal. It colors the faces of the dodecahedron key from Snap Together Puzzle Two - http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:950808 - The terminal display can be reproduced by using puzzle pieces.
comments.author: pmoews

comments.text:
There are 30^6 placements for the six pieces on a dodecahedron. Four of the pieces differ top-bottom which increases the number of possible placements to 16 x 30^6. On checking these placements 60 valid answers were found. The valid solutions occur in two types and if we consider color only there are two unique solutions; one where 2 blue pieces share 3 edges and one where two red pieces share 3 edges. I found single solutions for the puzzle using 4 green pieces and two blue pieces and the puzzle composed of 3 green pieces, one red piece, and 2 blue pieces.
Note: green = type01, blue = type02, red = type03.

title: All I want for my birthday is a big buddha ho!

description.text: Chrisniederer's buddha statue approx. 8 inches tall.  The first large test of the kbot3d large scale printer.Derived from my experiences with an ordbot, shapeoko, and prusa mendel and milled on a shapeoko from my own modified designs. Coming soon 16X16" bed.  Will print 30" tall.  After printing .3mm layers, it was treated to an acetone shower then vapour treatment to remove the haze.  My new printer will print 120 all day long.  Time to retire the prusa which has served well

comments.text: Nice print of the Buddha. Tell me more about this printer you've got that prints 30" high. I'm looking to get a larger format one myself.
comments.author: chrisniederer

comments.text: Based on photos of the ordbot with all plates cnc milled on my shapeoko.  A few of my own upgraded printed parts mostly for z wobble, extra feet, limit switch mounts and ramps mount.  Two 1800mm peices of makerslide . One cut in half for z, the other cut in thirds with one leg longer by the motor mounts plus z legs.  Originally I used an 8" bed and have upgrade to a 12" after finding out 4 8" beds were just too much weight for the y motor at decent speed.  Except for  the occasion bolt tightening itself on the z axis,  its a great printer and very accurate.  I can also swap out a dremel, 2w laser, and drag knife for other uses.  I can swap out beds and  tools in minutes.
comments.author: chrisniederer

comments.text: Nice Buddha ! What do you mean by acetone shower? Did you just spray it on or just used the vapour to treat it ? How were you infill and speed settings? I would love to make one
comments.author: stijnpa

comments.text: I find that vapor treating large parts doesnt work well.  I put items on a stand in a safe container.  I have a large jar of acetone with a coffer filter over the mouth and a few rubber bands to hold it in place.  I drizzle it over the print until it is smooth enough.  I let it dry then vapor treat it to remove the haze.

This is a small baffle for a 40mm fan mounted on the side of a prusa x-carriage. It directs half the fans air down over the plastic at the nozzle. My fan is mounted between the rods and slightly up so that it's bottom edge is 3mm up from the plane the end of the nozzle rides at. Half the air from the fan cools the top of the hot end barrel to protect the plastic in the Greg's extruder. This directs the other half of it's air down below the hot end and cools the print.
I've seen an immediate benefit in print quality with the directed cooling.
While printing this part, I had to manually fan it during the sloped part to keep the print clean. Slowing it down to %50 speed during that slope also helped to make it a nice clean plane.

description.text: My reprap setup involves a (mostly) Ecksbot mounted to a plywood base with an overhead spool holder.  Due to how the filament feeds, it rubs against the top rail of my machine as it prints.  This causes scuffing of the filament and plastic dust to fall on the print surface.  I remedied this by putting a piece of plastic corrugated wire loom on this threaded rod, which frankly drives me crazy to hear the filament skipping/clicking against it while printing.  Thought about wrapping it with tape or using a piece of hose instead, then it came to me...

print as-is (7.8mm inner diameter, 229mm length) or modify OpenSCAD .scad file to taste.  Make sure your heatbed is scorching hot and that your first layer gets pressed on good, this thing loves to curl!

Here is a roughly to scale model of the lighthouse of Alexandria, one of the 7 world wonders. It is located in Egypt, but is now in ruins due to three earthquakes. It was designed on autodesk inventor using measured dimensions and I made references to multiple drawings made by archaeologists. I chose to make and upload this project because it is one of the great engineering feats in the past, and is recognized as one of the 7 ancient world wonders.

SeeTheWorld

4 of these pieces prevented the top of two IKEA LACK tables stacked on top of each other from sliding off.

Works best when something heavy is on top. You can make it more permanent by gluing the printed parts to one of the tables, but this design was such that I could unstack them when I wanted to.

remixed_from.author: FuelCell250
remixed_from.title: Printrbot Simple (Early 2013) Direct-Drive Extruder 30mm Fan Mount

title: 40mm extruder fan adapter plate for late 2013 Printrbot Simple

description.text:
Figured out that most of the print failures I was encountering could be traced to heat creep (premature softening of filament as it passed through the extruder, causing the drive to slip and/or jam). Active cooling to the rescue.

Parametric model available as a public document on Onshape. I'm not sure how to link to it directly, but you can find it by searching for 40mm fan adapter plate for 2013 Printrbot Simple extruder. The document contains two part studios: one for the extruder plate plus one for my DC power connector mount.

Started with Joel Crane's 30mm fan mount plate. Initially hacked with OpenSCAD to add a larger diameter opening and assumed the 40mm fan bolt pattern would just match the extruder mounting bolts. Not quite.

Imported to Onshape using FreeCAD to convert the STL to STEP format. Used the imported object as a reference for a fresh sketch. This version (posted here as jmd-extruder-plate.stl) adds a spacer to clear the extruder mounting bolts and a new set of offset mounting holes (45mm diameter) for the fan.

Built with a 12v 40mm fan and DC power jack from Radioshack (!). The jack connects to a compatible power supply I happened to have for a small rotary multi tool. Evidently it would be possible to power this from the heated bed circuit on the printrboard, but for now the separate power supply is simple enough.

comments.text: Whoa. This is like a billion times better than my 30mm design (which was long before I discovered OpenSCAD). Nice work!
comments.author: FuelCell250

comments.text: Thanks! I am just learning to use Onshape and am very excited with what I can do now.

After printing out alot of the parts from the gingery lathe thing from sprocket1597, I saw that alot of the parts were missing, so I started designing the parts in freecad so I could get all of the parts to build the full lathe. Im still missing the tailstock assembly and such, but Ill add those when I get to that point.

This one contains the missing compound swivel, compound slide, headstock, and the leadscrew bearings for the side of the lathe body. The STL files are exact size and ready to print.

For anyone who's trying to print the files from sprocket1597, you need to either turn the size from metric to imperial and vice versa for the size to be right. In kisslicer, there's an option under "all models" called "inches -> mm", or you can set the size ratio to 25.4 or 2540%.

Edit: There has been a slight error in the headstock, and the new version has been uploaded now. If you have already printed the old version, I added the file Pads_fix_headstock, just glue those to the bottom of the headstock and they'll be fixed then. The error was that the bottom of the headstock where the mounts and slide grips were, it was short 1/16th of an inch, so I just updated it and added a fix for whoever had already printed the part so you dont have to reprint it again.

comments.text: Thanks for the things! I'm currently a ridiculous amount of hours into my lathe build. Just molded up the cross slide, and compound slide today, had some trouble with the swivel base though. Had to file and sand a lot of draft onto the core gap bit on the rectangle section as it just wont draw from the sand without pulling the core with it, and I don't think it should be all the way through, I will put some tape over one end to close it off more than likely (much like what Dave suggests when molding the bed casting)  Other wise, cheers for the parts mate, beats the hell out of making wood patterns!!

comments.text: Very cool! I want to start building the gingery lathe too!
comments.author: Tburris

comments.text: I found the headstock to be quite troublesome to cast normally, but if you use lost-pla casting, it'll work well that way. If you choose to use sand casting method, I would suggest a light coating in talc powder on the printed part and put a layer of saran wrap (plastic food wrap) laid over top of it. The sand will adhere to the plastic wrap but not the printed part, so it can be pulled out easy with little to no draft on parts.

description.text:
Consider this a "2.0" version. Completely redone, trying to strike the right balance with strength and speedy printing.

UPDATE: the notch for the filament is too loose. Uploaded a newer version for testing.

This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/5VD7uFm8NOI

I've always wanted to travel the world and see the 7 Wonders. Although I have never seen these wonders in person, I was inspired by their unique and incredible architecture to create this 7 Wonders mashup.

Color code:
Orange- Christ the Redeemer
Yellow- Taj Mahal
Red- El Castillo in Chichan Itza
Blue- Petra, Jordan
Purple- Great Wall of China
Brown- Colosseum
Green- Macchu Picchu

Treat this build as a puzzle and add on each wonder as you visit them! Or just print the two builds if you want it in fewer prints. I also included an alternate build that shows off Taj Mahal a bit better.

I spent a good deal of time trying to figure out how to mash these creations together. I first created Stacking El Castillos I decided to slice El Castillo and imbed Petra into it, given that Petra was built into stone.

Macchu Picchu was probably the trickiest to incorporate; I found an artist's rendition of what it may have looked at before it's collapse into ruin. http://www.theredheadedtraveler.com/book-review-machu-picchu-guidebook-self-guided-tour/

All wonders were created in Autodesk inventor and assembled in tinkercad except for Christ the Redeemer, which was created by JuanG3D. Check it out here! http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:744525
This project was extremely fun and i learned how to use Inventor more efficiently. All in all, it was a great learning experience. I may try the old seven wonders next!

All pictures from http://livenewshot.com/seven-wonders-of-the-world-2013/

Recommended printing instructions for Christ the Redeemer
Extruder: 205 degrees Celsius
Plate: 60 degrees Celsius
Resolution: 0.1 mm
Shells: 1
Infill: 30%
Rafts: No
Supports: No

Recommended printing instructions for others
Extruder: 215 degrees Celsius
Plate: 60 degrees Celsius
Resolution: 0.2 mm
Shells: 2
Infill: 15%
Rafts: No
Supports: No

[ Don't go selling it on eBay ]

You're Welcome

This RC Car was Designed to workaround the need for expensive rc car motors and intricate linkages. When I saw the Open RC truggy, I wanted one, but didn't want to also buy all of the Rc car part needed just to get it working. I used parts that any typical maker may hopefully have. The 9 gram steering servos are mounted to the top a-arms to take away the need for ball joints and a large amount of linkages. For the motor...motors, I recycled my DJI Phantom brushless motors. instead of using any gearing, I simplified the design by making them part of the rear wheels. This creates a great amount of speed while still having a surprising mount of torque. I used a hobby grade rc plane radio and power the car using two 3s lipo batteries. The fasteners vary from m3 nuts and bolts to plastic screws I was able to salvage. The front wheels rotate around a general skateboard bearing. I want to see what others are able to do with this platform. Hopefully improvements will come forth, making the vehicle a reliable open source machine.

https://youtu.be/eop02s6c_rk

https://youtu.be/3nNnf1uNtOQ

There are included color coded assembly files that hopefully help make assembly less problematic. Autodesk inventor was my CAD platform of choice. The STL files, for whatever reason, need to be enlarged by a factor of 10 in the object placement portion of your 3d printer software. I use a Prusa i3 from Folger technologies with a bunch of mods including a custom extruder and other parts. Repetier was the software I use to communicate with the printer. Slic3r is what I used to slice the objects. I would much rather a different plastic to print with other than PLA, but its the only plastic I can seem to get to stock to the bed.

comments.text: You want to use a standard flight controller to control the motors RPM , this will remove (most ) variations in motor speed compared to throttle register ( think quadcopter but with wheels) . A dirt cheap CC3d should be more than capable.

description.text:
Hermaphroditic Connector

Use the same connector on both sides.
~11A per Pin (read Instructions)

I needed a connector for my bed, and decided to design one in a way that i can print it twice and finish the connection, since I had the metal parts (connectors? Pins? don't know how they are called), but I didn't have the Plastic parts, i decided to use them in the Design for the connection.

Also the is a hole in the middle that you can use to hot glue a pin headers for the thermistor, and easily disconnect both of them at the same time.

NOTE: The tolerances for the Molex pins are quite right, they can't get of from the back, but they can from the front of the connector.

1. Print the connector twice
  2. Use the pins from a Molex connector, you can order them stand alone from eBay*
    (See the photos for were to put male and female parts)
  3. If you want to actually use it as a Hermaphroditic(Sexless) connector, then you have to connect the two middle pins together and the two outer pins together. **
  4. Connect them, I guess :P

*Since we use a Molex Pins they can handle 11Amps per Pin, If you find other pins that fit which are able to handle more Amps, please inform me.

** In this configuration it will handle double the Amperage of the individual pins.

description.text:
There's something intensely organic and elegant about this end-cap, but more importantly it just feels amazingly perfect in your hand, like it's hugging your fingers. It is a pure pleasure to use, to screw on or off. Its subtle curves are pleasing to the eye as well.

We are used to simple planar curves in ordinary life, this is a complex 3D curve which we seldom encounter in the real world--they are hard to manufacture by ordinary means. Which makes this a perfect example piece of a part suitable for 3D printing.

It has a threaded center-hole, and is designed to cap onto a 2" ID cylinder.

Probably not many people have that specific need, but the design on this part is so human-friendly and pleasant that it should serve as an example of fantastic design and I hope people will download it to learn from it.

It is the perfect end-cap.
Has a 3/8"-16 threaded center hole. The ID is 2".

comments.text: It's PERFECT!

To my surprise, there was no warping whatsoever. I'm keeping the PLA version in the dishwasher for now to see how it holds up. I would still recommend using ABS but if you only have PLA it does seem to work.
Print wheel and spindle separately. Wheel doesn't need any rafts or supports. Spindle needs supports. After printing spindle, clean raft material and use drill bits to clean up holes.

title: K-Cup Adapter for non-official K cups in a 2.0 machine

description.text: Ok so I found that the keurig K cups that are not made by the keurig company wont work in the 2.0 keurig machines and I found out that if you take a used official K cup that works with the keurig machine and gently peel the foil from a working K cup and place over an unofficial k cup and it will work in the 2.0 and I was thinking how to make something that can hold the foil in place and this is what I came up with and I tested it on my keurig 2.0 and it worked, it was just a tight fit and warped a bit from the heat of the machine and I made the test print out of PLA so I had to let it cool a bit before I would try to brew another cup it does work and feel free to improve the design if you can. just post a link to any updates / redesigns in the comments so I can check it out thanks.

print should just slide across the top of an unofficial K cup and an official K cup foil lid gently pealed off the cup and slid in to the print on top of the unofficial k cup to get the keurig 2.0 to use generic k cups.

comments.text: I wonder if it will work by it's self if printed in a florescent colored filament like the clips do.

comments.text: it will work no matter the material its printed with because U need to take the foil cover from an official K cup and U just snap the adaptor to the unofficial k cup and then slide the foil from the official k cup under the circular side and the machine will see it as an official k cup and there U go

title: Gerber Suspension Slide Case - Horizontal Mount

description.text:
Update: 11/12/16
I didn't like how the corners of the case felt on my arm, so I added chamfers. The new file is called Mod 2. I also made the smaller belt loop a little larger. It's now 37.5 mm wide

Remix of https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:927363.

I like my tool mounted along my belt to keep a low profile. I added belt loops to mount horizontally.

Took it camping for a week after printing it and it held up great.

Smallest belt loop has inner dimensions of approximately 1.4" x .15" (35.5 mm x 4 mm). This belt loop was a little tight for my belt and required filing to get it to fit.
Printed standing up with a raft and support everywhere. I used 30% infill and a 3 layer shell.

comments.text:
It stays in great! And I like that you designed in the "click".
My approach was based off of the case that came with the tool, which had two belt loops. I considered making it clip on, but didn't have the time to think it out.

comments.text: That is a great idea!  I love that it can be printed all in one go, rather than as multiple pieces like the original, and the belt loops are printed in the strongest orientation. Zip tying the power connector directly to the board wasn't very sturdy so I created this mount for the power connector.  Zip tie the mount where the connector goes and then use the nut on the connector to mount it to the bracket.  When cleaning up the mount be sure not to remove the little nubs at the opening of the U.  They are there to help hold the power connector in place.  It should pop in with a satisifying snap.  This mount may work for those who mounted their printrboard on the inside also.

I was asked by my friend to make an arm. Only one muscular arm. So i made it. In .stl I added some kind of stand. Enjoy.
Easier to deal with fan shroud for printrbot play that does not block view, allows for easy mid-print filament changes, but still does its job.

Both parts are printed with standard settings. You might need to trim the lower fan mount connecting points to fit them to the upper part. The upper fan is mounted to the side closest to the extruder. The lower fan is mounted on the outside or side furthest from the hot end, to prevent interference with bed mount screws.

author: JYoung

description.text:
This is a simple Spool Rack inside a standard 50L storage box. I had to design this as there is a lot of humidity where I live and it had started affecting my filament.

This can hold around 8 narrow spools of filament.

It uses a 1'' PVC pipe as the rack.

This is super convenient to use as the rack is on a hinge so that it is easy to replace spools.

I added some de-humidifying bags, and sealed all the holes with silicone sealant.

I've also included some "supports" for the nuts/bolts as the plastic is thin and I wanted to divide the pressure over a larger area than the screw hole itself.

I've included the scad files so that you can make any changes you like.
It is just correct scaled and correct oriented and ready to print. I have made it from PLA, with 40% fill. Weight is 19g. In my case I need also 5mm longer bolts for motors.

&
amp;C's don't specifically require attribution it does state that the author retains all rights over their works, and it is generally considered best practice to at least have an attribution link.
comments.author: eloper

comments.text: There is no such cartridge as a .45 magnum. There's the .45 ACP, which is a centerfire pistol cartridge (and therefore generally can't be fired in revolvers without the use of a special cylinder and a moon clip), but you're probably thinking of a .44 magnum, which is a revolver cartridge. Also, you have not attached a .stl file, which woud be needed to print this model. Finally, the model does not look well-adapted for 3D printing. I see significant overhangs. You might consider slicing the gun in half and laying each half flat. Then once the halves are printed out, you would glue them together.

title: Our Dream House in Hong Kong.. a place that every hongkonger spend a lifetime to reach

description.text:
Hong Kong is a place full of housing units, residential buildings. It's different from other places, the most significant building isn't a special landmark. To most hong kong people, a simple unit to live in, is always what they think and work for entire life in fact.

Every Hongkonger desires to have a housing unit. People work hard for buying a unit which costs 15 times of the annual household income. That's why Hong Kong ranks world's No 1 for 'most unaffordable' housing. (a survey of 360 cities by US-based consultancy Demographia)

Hard lives make Hong Kong people only focus on stock market, to earn some extra income. Hard lives make Hong Kong people can't breath, lose creativity and space to do research and explore new things. Hard lives make Hong Kong people care about time, lose patience, become impatient and lack of foresight mindset.

This series of residential building 3D model let you easily understand how stuffy Hong Kong is. It's a reminder to you and to your government that please don't let your living place become Hong Kong. It's a warning and a lesson to the world.

Hope you love it and hate it. This is the most meaningful stuff I could do for landmark of Hong Kong. Thanks for reading.

The customizable version updated on 14 August 2015. It could change between types of blocks, like Y-type, H-type or even hexagon. You can control the level of the block. It's more like a satire and a complain to the society. For your reference, in Hong Kong, there are 221 blocks of trident block type Y, 852 blocks of harmony block type. There still have Slab type, I block type, Ziggurat type, Concord type, New Cruciform type, etc .... each block store over 800 families.. you can't imagine if you haven't come hong kong or haven't print the block..

It's my first time to use OpenSCAD to create customizable model. I learn it by watching youtube tutorial, and look at the cheat sheet provided in OpenSCAD. It is still not quite clear and lack of good learning resources in internet. But the result is really useful and convenience, let 3D modelling technique reach a new level. Everything can self generate once has been well established. So I strongly suggest designer to try it. Build the complicated element in 3D software like 3dsmax, use OpenSCAD to generate a regular pattern.

I make this series residential building by taking photos near my place. Actually, everywhere I live and everyday I travel, also got plenty of such buildings. So easy to look at them in details.

I start from scratch by using 3dsmax. By achieving the right scale, I took plenty of pictures, look at the top view from Google map and try print it in different version see if printable for about 7cm tall. I focus on making the blocks at small size, about 7 cm tall. Spend only 2-3hrs, you could print a block quickly. However, you can't put too much details on a 7cm object, otherwise it will crash ugly because of details, such as I want to add air conditioner in each house before.

I think one of the special thing in 3D printing is easy to duplicate item with one design. And Hong Kong got thousands of building copies.. The item that duplicated most here.

Layer Height : 0.12mm - 0.14mm
Shell : 0.4mm
Fill Density : 0 %

Hope you enjoy it!

This sand Castle was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/5v

This is a sand castle mold that is not like a classic sand castle. It is a geometric free form castle. This is my first ever design. The first time printing I had to stop it because it wasn't coming out right, so the second time I printed it upside down. There were some things that I would want to improve if I could print it again. These are making some of the walls thicker and having the tops of the towers line up with the towers. I made and new design with those improvements, but I did not get to print it. I made this in a CAD and 3-D printing class.

I first started by adding a block on the bottom. I then added the rectangle tower and then the cylinder tower. I put and triangle on top of the rectangle tower and a cone on top of the cylinder tower. I then added the half sphere and four sided pyramid to the base. Then I grouped all the pieces together. Next I took the grouped together pieces and put a block over them. Then I made the pieces a hole. I then grouped the pieces and the block together and then took out some of the pieces of the block to save material when it was printing. After it was done printing, I filled in with pink Kinetic Sand and took pictures if it.
I printed my sand castle at 100% scale with default settings and with rafts and supports on. The castle is 62mm tall by 82mm wide by 97mm long.

Updated: Updated hand to hollow.

Here is a texture test using the recent scan of hollies hand, where I fixed several issues and opened up the fingers.
The images I used for texturing though were from about 6 months earlier and had some heavy shadowing, so not ideal for texturing. I hope to get some better photos soon.

I intend to make this into a passive hand for now. So I will be using a full colour 3D printer. These are quite fragile so I'll likely reinforce it with resin and a silicone outer layer. In fact the image I've added of the broken antibody model is made of just this material with an added layer of colourless RTV silicone added. It works quite well and definitely removes the grainy fragile feeling of the print.

Later on I will hope to add coloured sheaths to the Anthromod V2.0 prosthetic model.

Of course trying to get these printed costs time and money. A way that you can help me is to donate to http://www.gofundme.com/prosthetic-hand

Periodic structure known from the pyrochlore crystal structure in solid state physics (network of corner-sharing tetrahedra). In these crystal systems ions reside on the corners of tetrahedra and experience magnetic exchange with each other (see https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spin_ice)

Here, a subset of tetrahedra is carved from the lattice that beautifully forms a tetrahedron itself.

Not easy to print due to a large number of overhangs and bridges. Finally managed using PLA and about 0.2mm layers.

author: quadmovr

description.text:
So I have a cover for my printer that I made to keep the heat in (to prevent cracking on taller prints). But it turns out that even with the heated bed and print head it was not hot enough.  
So I got one of these little Lasko electric heaters from Walmart (online not in store). It was cheap (like $15) and it has a fan and no tilt switch (safety for turning over). This is made to fit on a desk at work.  
So my cover is made of plane old schedule 40 PVC pipe. I tried the heater by clamping the cord to the top and pointing it down towards the build platform and it works great. It gets plenty hot inside now but not so hot as to be dangerous. So I made this hanger so I could quickly attach it and even point it.  
Print solid (or close, I used 80% infill) and then drill and bolt to the back corner of the Lasko. The holes in the mount match up perfectly with the space between the fins.

author: hamadada123

description.text:
Single-axis gimbal for mounting a Canon IXUS 220HS to a multicopter.

Consists of two parts:

  • "Holder", which mounts to the copter and holds the servo in place.
  • "Frame", that tightly fits the IXUS 220HS (fix with a tripod screw from below) and is mounted inside of the holder using an M3 bolt and a nut from one side and fixed to the servo arm on the other side. The back is hollowed to minimize weight.

I fixed the holder to the copter using velcro tape and control the camera via USB/CHDK/scripting. Designed for a MG946R servo which has far enough power. This is not designed to stabilize the camera, but simply to allow tilting for non-vertical shots.

Printing with about 25% infill should give enough stability, maybe even less.

title: Sleeved tubing construction for Barrychuck's Thing O Matic Z stage mod

description.text: This is a derivative or alternate construction method of the Thing O Matic Z stage mod by barrychuck http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:6184 . [If you can tell me how to do a linked derivative I will make it so] The hole enlargement for the 21/32" tubing can be problematic to do accurately. I found a way to do it in my shop using more commonly available drill sizes and tools. Accurately. Basically, if the pieces of 21/32" tubing are sleeved, with 21/32" tubing then they fit perfectly inside 11/16" standard drill hole. I will otherwise confess that I found this out accidentally by thinking the 11/16" would be perfect (slipped the tubing in a Forester bit cap and thought it fit good) but didn't do a test hole. Accidental or not - it works great. Please remember - this is just a construction alternative derivative for http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:6184 and only helps construction - so that thing itself is best for discussion and commentary on the mod itself. Discussion on this page should be on this construction method.

Please read all instructions thoroughly all the way through. Then proceed.
Checking your bits:
You'll need a 5/8 and a 11/16" drill bit. Preferably Forester as illustrated. As we use the 5/8" to index the 11/16" it needs to be perfectly on center. Surprisingly - many aren't.
If you don't check your bits, and particularly the 5/8" we use to index, then your quill will be off center and thence your 11/16" bore. If your 11/16" isn't perfect then you'll just get a bigger hole. Not great, but not off center.
One simple enough way to check your bit is to spin it (by hand) after indexing it in the steps below. There should be zero runout / wangle on your board as you rotate the bit in the hole. Your second hole will also show perfect concentricity with the original hole if everything is good.
Preparing the Wood:
We counter bore a larger hole on exactly the same center. To do this accurately requires a drill press or a mill. Preferentially also use Forster bits.
First step is indexing. Chuck a 5/8" Forster bit and lower it into the hole. It should fit perfectly. Now clamp this wood down while still with the bit inside. Preferentially with a backing board (which I didn't use due to my vise). This indexes the drill and importantly the quill.
Here's a good point to check that 5/8" bit for concentricity. If you turn the chuck nothing should bind or move and the bit should rotate perfectly within the hole.
Second step is drilling. Check a 11/16" Forster bit and start a cut. Just a hair. Check that the outer edge is perfectly concentric with the hole. It should be - but maybe you bumped it? the drill is bent? Check it as stated above. After checking this complete drilling the hole through.
Repeat this for the 2nd bearing hole set.
You may need to clean up the bottom side of your piece depending on use of backing board, drill speed, etc. I do this with roughish sandpaper at a 45 across the edge to just cut off any slivers and flash.
Preparing the tubing:
Cut your 21/32" tubing to your desired lengths per the original Z stage mod. I used 3" and 5.25" as my metric ruler wasn't handy.
Cut two additional pieces of that tubing for the outer sleeves. They don't need to be full length - just to span the height of the Z state assembly plus a little. I used 2.25" and cut two pieces.
Cut a slot the entire length. I marked mine with a straight edge - but it's not critical to be perfectly straight - though it does count for style points! I braced the tubing in a clamp with soft jaws as shown to make the holding and slotting easier.
Use some sand paper to clean the flash off the edge. backside of a No 11 may work too. You want both sides of the edge inside and out smooth and free of burrs.
Slide your sleeves on - they should fit perfectly. If not - adjust them.
Now bond your sleeve to your tube. I used my propane torch and soldered them, but for this low-strength application you could as well use super glue or ThreadLock Green to wick in. Just be sure it's all clean and scuffed. Trim up your edges if anything walked while you did this.
Test fit these into your holes. They should go in smoothly but with a small amount of friction. Tighter is better - but we'll pin these so as long as it's centered and not wobbling it's OK. (shouldn't be if drilled in a press)
Now with fitment checked you can insert the bushings. I found I didn't need any rolled edges. The bushings went most of the way in. To make sure they stayed put I again used ThreadLock Green. Super Glue would work. Apply a bead and firmly set it into place. Be very careful not to get it inside!
Let this dry. When thoroughly dry (which isn't just when you think it is dry - RTM) you should use your 3/8" rod and pop the inner bushing free and move it about. Then set them so the rod slides through as this alignment (or close) is necessary when installing in the MakerBot.
Install in the Z Stage:
Now you can install your sleeved tubes in the Z-stage. This follows the original build.
Myself I utilized about 1/8" overhang on the top to make it easier to apply a setting bead of glue later and keep it out of my bearing. 
To do this easily just invert the Z-stage assembly and level it. Then install the bushing tubes until they hit bottom. Now they're spaced perfectly out at the same height as the M-3 bolts nearby. Apply a drop or two of super glue to the bottom of each tube. Only that now.
You're done and now have perfectly aligned tubes for your BarryChuck Z stage mod.
After all normal fttment into the chassis then you should apply beads of superglue around the tubing to lock it in. Again - nothing new here. Just reminding you to not fully set the tubes until after chassis fitment.

This extruder is a derivative of Zach's plastruder and I'm really excited to share it. The main difference is that exchanged the idler wheel with a Delrin plunger. This reduces the overall size of the extruder uses two fewer layers. Using a plunger allows the force exerted on the filament perpendicular to its direction of travel to be adjusted while the extuder is running. I mounted the electronics along the side, so I can view the teeth on the filament on the way to the thermal barrier and adjust the force to get the tooth depth I like. With this design, changing the filament takes approximately ten seconds from when the barrel becomes hot enough. The motor can be removed with out disassembling the housing. There is, however, a flaw in this particular design. The captive nut holding the plunger screw will crack the acrylic if you tighten things too much. In the next version I will have this fixed. This design is also based on a larger diameter timing pulley, so the filament guide is a little off. See it in action http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=HMjVrmLJvIU Subversion http://svn.makerbot.com/users/charles/paxtruder/

comments.text: Interesting design.  How often do you have to tighten the adjustment screw as the delrin wears down?
comments.author: Wade

comments.text: I've never had to tighten it due to wear and have never noticed any. Delrin has very low friction with ABS and is pretty strong. I tried this with a bit of PTFE, which got a channel squished into it, but also did not wear.
comments.author: Wade

comments.text: You should add a 606 bearing on to the end of your motor shaft so that the linear pressures that you place on the shaft with the delrin wont kill your motor. That's how mine was killed (over-tightened idler-wheel). Also, it makes the plastic flow much more consistent.
comments.author: cyrozap

comments.text: Already on it. I have the 606 mod in the extruder I'm currently using and it's a nice improvement. I'll thingiverse a new design once I fix the acrylic cracking problem. I might also include a mod that will obsolete the thermal barrier retainer.
comments.author: cyrozap

author: GaryPatterson

description.text:
Adapter to attach an all metal E3Dv6 hotend to the Overlord 3D printer.

See instructions tab for more details.

Very easy to print, but very hard to get dimensions right.

I am providing it more as an example than as a useful print, since I really doubt it will fit nicely your printer without having to tune dimensions first.

That is why I am also providing the 3D model on the files tab. It is designed using Fusion360 (it's free for hobby or small business!), but should be editable by other CAD software as well.

So I recommend you print it once, check how it fits, decide changes and edit CAD in order to print again. (Maybe you can make it work just using slicer scale tool, but I doubt it).

Make sure it fits very tight both the hotend and the effector plate. You should be able to move printing head grabbing from the hotend by hand (when it is cold!) and nor the hotend nor the plastic piece should move respect to the effector plate.

Print two pieces in ABS in order to support high temperatures and fit them together.
I printed mine at 40mm/s, 20% infill, 0.2 mm layer heigth and NO supports needed.

More info on this post: http://www.dreammaker.cc/forum/viewtopic.php?f=7&t=177

comments.text: Nice and simple design. I might design something similar like this but with mounting for 2 cooling fans (currently only print with PLA). But not sure if I have the sufficient skills to design it (heh). What are the advantages of using the E3Dv6 though?
comments.author: AFIF

comments.text: E3Dv6 is a very popular all metal hotend. It does not have plastic tubes (ptfe, peek) in the hot area, so it can achieve higher temperatures without having to care for the internal plastic melting when reaching 250+ ºC, like happens on the original Overlord hotend. It is also smaller in size and much ligther, enabling you to use higher acceleration values with higher precision. It also has a great variety of nozzle sizes and materials to choose from, so you can change them easily. I recommend using the original E3Dv6 hotend, because clones seems similar what are quite worse regarding to materials and internal geometry.
comments.author: AFIF

comments.text: Thanks Luis! Since currently I only print with PLA, should I notice any difference in print quality by using the E3Dv6? Less blobs/ooze/stringing?
comments.author: luisonoff

comments.text: I don't think you will see noticeable changes in blobs/ooze/stringing. You would see a bit of difference in precision when using higher accelerations, and you will be able to change nozzle size, in order to get higher resolution prints or faster thicker ones when you need.
comments.author: AFIF

comments.text: Great. Thanks!

Metric Bolt too long to mount your current or new fan; print these spacers to meet your needs.

Designed in Blender 2.74 Release (Opensource) https://www.blender.org/features/2-75/
Take care when printing that your layer sizes are small enough they don't add to more than the thickness of the spacer. Example: For 1mm make sure your layers don't exceed the 1mm height, Wrong: (First layer 0.8mm, Last layer 0.4mm, Walls 0.4mm. layer size= 0.1mm) Works: (First layer 0.4mm, Last layer 0.4mm, Walls 0.4mm, layer size = 0.2mm)

infill should be 100% for the spacers to ensure integrity.
Suggest layer heights of 0.1mm; and for first and last layer and wall thickness use 0.2mm or 0.4mm (max).

In honor of the release of the latest Daft Punk album, I wanted to print a set of helmets. I couldn't find a decent mesh on thingiverse (I AM DISAPPOINT), so I put this together.
This is a ready to print model of Guy-Manuel's Daft Punk helmet.

I gave these out as party gifts, who doesn't like a little daft punk?
The model is just dying for remixes. Keychains, magnets, gear shift knobs, lets do this people! I've uploaded a thicker model, as the thin model is 84 megs (poor tessellation settings on my part). Once I've regenerated the thinner mesh, I'll add it to the thing. I'll upload more pics of it once I have another print, gave em all away! For the matching set, print the Thomas helmet as well:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:94603
Happy printing!
